td.p: Maria G, Matt V & Adam B

p.span: There’s a fungus that turns ants into zombies.
It hijacks their brains, controls their bodies, and then kills them.
Yeah, The Last of Us was based on a real thing.

a.span: Apple’s AI team is not okay

p.span: Apple’s head of foundation models, Ruoming Pang, is
, a big move that highlights how intense the race for AI talent has become.
Pang led the team behind Apple’s core AI models, the same ones powering features like Genmoji and the new version of Siri.
Meta confirmed the hire and reportedly offered him a package worth tens of millions a year (though short of previously reported
This is part of a
by Meta, which is building out a “superintelligence” team by bringing in top names from Apple, OpenAI, Anthropic and others.
Meanwhile, Apple’s AI division has been dealing with internal changes, flagging morale, and a growing interest in using third-party models like OpenAI’s.
There’s been a shift in leadership, too. With Pang out, his team is being restructured under new management.
Meta is snapping up top AI talent with massive pay packages.
Apple is testing third-party models as internal friction grows.
Leadership reshuffles suggest Apple’s AI priorities are shifting.

span.b: AI team? More like AI ex-team

p.span: And while John Giannandrea is still
, decision-making around consumer AI now largely sits with Craig Federighi and Mike Rockwell, following delays and a lukewarm response to Apple Intelligence.
Altogether, it shows how Apple’s AI strategy is still taking shape, and just how aggressive Meta is in going after the people building it.
Can I get one of those mega sign-on bonuses?

td.h3: Is Apple falling behind in the AI talent race?

a.p: Not yet, Apple always plays the long game

td.p: I'm launching a new B2B tech marketing agency with AI. Claude came up with my brand colors and fonts, and even drafted my brand guide when I attached an example guide I created in the past. Claude and I debated alternatives and Claude came up with the best options for my ICP.

a.span: Tell us how you’re using AI! →

p.span: Boston University researchers have built an
called PodGPT that learns from science and medical podcasts.
Instead of relying only on written text, it listens to real conversations, interviews, expert chats, lectures, and turns them into training data.
In total, the model absorbed over 3,700 hours of spoken content.
They then
with quizzes in subjects like biology, maths and medicine (even in different languages), and found that adding this kind of audio content helped the AI give more accurate and detailed responses.
AI can learn from how experts talk, not just what they write
PodGPT showed stronger results by training on real-world conversations
This method could help with health diagnoses and learning across languages
It’s a step towards building smarter, more human-like tech that understands how science is actually discussed.
The researchers say this could also make science more accessible in different languages and help people better understand topics that impact their health, education and day-to-day decisions.
The AI listened to the audiobook AND took notes.

p.span: TikTok may soon be

to a group of non-Chinese investors, including Oracle, to comply with U.S. law, with a new version of the app set to launch in September, pending Chinese approval, while the current app would disappear by March 2026.

p.span: No, future growth needs bold moves - 41%

span.i: “Microsoft in particular needs to focus on selling licenses for CoPilot to enterprises with worker training. Workers aren’t changing how they do their work using CoPliot when ChatGPT is already part of their work flow.”
